head.supplied: St. Helens, 25 Nov. 1858. ¶ ¶ When I wrote last I was at Yambuck, but the visit did me no good, I was nearly a fortnight at Suters, but a week ago I got so ill, that Mr. Suter wrote to George, who ca...

div.p: RB MSS M number, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens, Melbourne.

Transcribed 27 March 1989. Corrected 16 October 1992.
St. Helens, 25 Nov. 1858.

When I wrote last I was at Yambuck, but the visit did me no good, I was nearly a fortnight at Suters, but a week ago I got so ill, that Mr. Suter wrote to George, who came at once & took me home the next day, I feared to be laid up at Suters, which would have caused them trouble & I did not want to be longer parted from my darling husband & our dear little one; life is so short, who knows how long we wil be spared for each other. — Georgie is growing fast, he can walk a good distance beside us, when we take a walk. We drive now every day an hour or two, in the hope that it will strengthen me. I am still getting thinner & weaker, God only knows how it will end. — St. Helens is not sold yet. — We have a gentleman here to night, so must soon close this. We never ask company now, I am to nervous to entertain, instead of it cheering me up, I feel quite unable to do anything. — Georgie talks a great deal about the little Suters. The little Eliza had jammed her finger in the door, he cannot forget that at all. — We have already killed several snakes again, they have come out so early & make us feel very uneasy. I expect Edward wishes for rain, the farmers & settlers here are praying for it. My dear George sends his love to you all. —
